newsitem.title: FRANCE: Loss-making French Infonie seeks partner.
newsitem.headline: Loss-making French Infonie seeks partner.

text.p: French online information service company Infonie, faced with slower than expected growth in subscriber numbers, is planning a capital increase and a link-up with another company, a spokeswoman said on Wednesday.
Infonie, launched in October 1995, reported a 1996 loss of 149.2 million francs ($25.6 million) which sent its shares tumbling by 27 percent on Wednesday to 100 francs.

The spokeswoman said that Infonie had 30,313 subscribers at the end of March and should reach break-even in 1998 or 1999 after the break-even point is brought down to 85,000 subscribers in 1997 from the current level of 100,000.

Infonie's chairman and chief executive officer Bruno Bonnel said this week that a capital increase was necessary but he did not give any details on the size or timing of the operation. A rights issue is one of the possibilities open to the group.

The spokeswoman said that Infonie was having talks with other online companies in France. "We are having discussions with all the other French players on the market with an eye a future alliance in whatever form," she said.
Other French players are Wanadoo, of France Telecom, Microsoft unit MSN, Club Internet as well as AOL and CompuServe.
Company sources said that a merger with Wanadoo, launched a year ago, was a possibility.
Infonie, a French language service also available in Belgium and Canada, is very strong in interactive games while Wanadoo is strong on information and databases.
Infonie was launched on the Nouvel Marche start-up market in 1996 at a price of 450 francs per share.
The company is for 46 percent owned by Infogrames Participation which represents the founders, Societe Financiere et Industrielle Gaz et Eaux, Production Marcel Dassault and bank Paribas.
